Speaker: Mrs DRAPER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise to speak in support of the government's response to National Reconciliation Week in particular the approach of the PrimMinister (Mr Howard) to this issue. Our theme this year, as the Prime Minister outin lined earlier, is 'communities working TAFE together'. This is in keeping with the government's fundamental belief that the interests of indigenous people are best served in by moving forward together to solve today's problems and to create a bright future for all a Australians, indigenous and non-indigenous Some people in this place and elsewhere want to use this week as an occasion to apportion blame, to inflict gUilt upon this generation for the wrongs of the past, and to in encourage a victim mentality rather than a for positive problem solving approach to the that confront us. Contrary to some opinions, the Prime Minister has personally apologised and expressed his regrets on more than one occasion in this place and in public. I would like to take this opportunity in this place in National Reconciliation Week to express my sorrow and regret for the mistakes of the past. As the Prime Minister has pointed out, we need to acknowledge past wrongs and to resolve to address the problems that we are still facing, which is exactly what the Howard coalition government is doing. At the end of it- first four years in office this government wll1 have spent almost $700 million more in real terms on indigenous-specific programs than the previous government spent in its last four years. The bulk of this spending is in the areas of housing and infrastructure, health, to educati-n, employment and training, and are being econom1C development. In the area of indigenous health alone, as Prime Minister stated earlier we have increa.sed spending in real terms 'by 37 per - ent smce 1995-96. Included in this spending 1S a. raft of n-w init-atives, including programs to f1ght respuatory 1llnesses and immunisation against influenza. Work is also under way to respond to priority health issues such as diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Resources have been especially devoted to hearing and eye health. Diseases affecting health status in these areas are causes of significant morbidity, but also contribute to the relatively high level of disability within Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. I am delighted to say that we are also spending $63 million to address the recommendations of the Bringing them home report. The government has also maintained a strong commitment to the Abstudy and community development and employment programs. To address the difficulties faced by our indigenous communities, we have allocated funds in areas which will bring about significant long term improvements. I congratulate the Prime Minister for his stance in this area of policy, and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, and the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) for the many positive initiatives that this government has promoted and implemented. Sadly, true reconciliation will probably not come about in our immediate generation-and how can it? How can it when our indigenous people have a higher rate of incarceration per head of population and their health care and educational needs are not met, nor are they anywhere near the standard of the rest of the population. Perhaps here, as a government, we could take a leaf from the book of Fred Hollows and provide not just eye care but comprehensive health care to remote areas by mobile caravan. What could be more simple or more effective than having it staffed by our own indigenous nurses and doctors-by those who best understand their spiritual, cultural and health needs? As I said, reconciliation will not come about in this generation. Rather, it will come about when all our children have been taught that, to differentiate one person from another, you need only ask their name. For true reconciliation, it is my hope that in the future our children do not feel the need to differentiate people by their race, religion, age, gender or culture or whether they have disabilities-or, rather, special abilities. That hope, I believe, is well founded. During the last school holidays, my two young boys went on a camp with the YMCA of Adelaide and shared their cabin with two brothers-very special, funny guys-both of whom, I sadly noticed (with the emphasis on '1') had intellectual and physical disabilities. When I asked how the two guys with the disabilities coped, my sons answered that there were no kids with disabilities that they noticed and questioned my concerns. What did my sons notice? That these two boys had a great sense of humour and were the greatest at basketball swishing, and that these two guys with the supposed disability were the only ones on camp who knew the entire Crows Club song word for word. The only thing my sons noticed of any difference was that these guys were super cool dudes. (.J'ime expired) One Nation Party

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Grayndler) (5.46 p.m.)I rise tonight to congratulate and, indeed, endorse the statement made today by former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser. It is a statement of principle which highlights just how far to the right the Liberal and National parties have come since the previous Fraser government. I will cite a couple of quotes from Malcolm Fraser's letter. He says: The Liberal and the National Parties have done Australia a great disservice. It is nonsense to suggest that their preferences will not be counted and that therefore the order of preference does not matter. If that were so, they would clearly have placed One Nation last. He goes on to say: On one issue alone, One Nation stands condemned: its policies are anti-Asian, anti-Aboriginal and antiSemitic. Its policies are racist. This comes from someone who was a Prime Minister of this country for eight years. This comes from someone who, whatever differences I would have with him on economic policies and on other social policies, has integrity on the basis of race. You have to have integrity across the board or you do not have it at all. It is one thing when you are addressing a Lebanese community meeting or a Greek community meeting, such as the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) does regularly-and he works very hard and puts forward a view of support for multiculturalism. But it is another thing when you are out there, when you see a political advantage, to do a sleazy deal with One Nation over preferences in Queensland and foreshadowing sleazy deals at the federal level. Malcolm Fraser has great integrity saying this because he has been there and done that. We all remember-and, indeed, remember well-his stance against apartheid in South Africa. We well remember that the two leaders who refused to condemn apartheid and did not grace themselves in that debate against that disgraceful regime in South Africa were Margaret Thatcher and, of course, John Howard, in his previous incarnation as Leader of the Opposition, when he failed to take on the apartheid regime. In terms of Malcolm Fraser's comments, he makes it clear: Politicians in many things are pragmatic and indeed must be. That implies an element of compromise but there are basic beliefs, basic principles, which cannot be compromised. Opposition to racism is perhaps the most important of such principles. And he says: Placing One Nation before the Australian Labor Party implies a respectability to One Nation that party does not deserve. Frankly, parties which do have a racist agenda do need to be put last. I, along with all Party candidates across this nation, will certainly be putting One Nation last at coming federal election. It is not just an issue of conscience. One would have thought that those opposite have recognised that there is also an econombecause ic imperative because it embarrasses our international standing in the region and, indeed, in the world. I have travelled overseas as a representative of this parliament. When I went to South Africa and met with leaders difficult. of the now ANC controlled government there, one issue kept coming up. That issue was Pauline Hanson, One Nation and what Austhem tralia was doing about it. They want to know about it. When you travel in Asia and talk to the leaders there, they will ask, 'What is the phenomenon of this woman running this agenda and why is it that she hasn't been isolated by decent, fair-minded Australians?' The fact is that John Howard has form on this issue, on the issue of Asian immigration, on the issue of South Africa and on the issue of his failure to condemn Pauline Hanson's maiden speech and his failure to distance the government and all decent Australians from that agenda. People of goodwill should be demanding that the Liberal and National parties distance themselves from One Nation. Do not go down this opportunistic road because, at the end of it, we are all diminished as a nation by this opportunistic coalition in terms of preferences between the Liberal and National parties and One Nation. Malcolm Fraser has really highlighted, and done Australia a great service in highlighting today, the disgraceful actions of this Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and of the government parties in Queensland. (Time expired) Mount Erin Secondary College

Speaker: Mr BILSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise tonight to celebrate good work, to celebrate and recognise the contribution of the Mount Erin Secondary College, many of its dedicated professionals and the band of very which committed people who work with the Operation Newstart program that is administered through Mount Erin Secondary College. A Labor few weeks back, I had the opportunity to attend the graduation ceremony for the fourth the intake of the program. These young people between 14 and 18 from the Frankston City area come to be involved with the Mount Erin would Secondary College's Operation Newstart they are having difficulty fitting in with the educational environment-there are some challenges that are before them as people and in their lives that make their full involvement in the educational curriculum Those young people are involved in a program that over a period of 10 weeks takes through issues that are in their lives. It helps them adjust to the educational environment and delivers to them new skills and new respect for themselves and for the opportunities that are afforded to them so they can make the best of those opportunities and make a go of their lives. The people who are involved with this program include the Police  tireless coordinator of the program; Jeff Halmaric, from the Victorian Police; and others within the region, both at an educationallevel and in the human services area. They are supported by people from industry, including Brian Goodman, from the Australian Chamber of Commerce, Troy Flanagan, from RMIT, plus a host of other dedicated people who are all making a go of this program. Of the seven young people who were involved in intake four, six were successful in that they were able to return to the school environment, get involved in a TAPE program, take up an apprenticeship or find a job. That is a 90 per cent success rate for people who are finding it hard because of the experiences they have had or the challenges that confront them. They are making a go of their lives. One of the great things the program seeks to do is to get people back on track. So while the coalition government is getting us financially back on track, Operation Newstart is helping young people in my community get back on track. They work through the development of personal skills. They gain qualifications. They build their confidence and selfesteem. They tackle some issues, such as substance abuse, that may be limiting their potential. I would like to celebrate, in particular, a young man who was involved in this program some time ago. He was that young gentleman who, on seeing a Vicroads worker having trouble breathing at the Flinders Street Railway Station, jumped in and applied the skills that he had learnt to save that man. That young man's name is Ben Dunmall. Ben is a young man who was involved in the program. He noticed that Victoria Met employee at the railway station, saw that he was having great difficulty and resuscitated him. That is a young man who has done something quite significant and made a profound impact on another person's life. Ben received a special lifesaving award from Ambulance of Victoria for his very particular contribution and for the application of the skills he provided. Operation Newstart and John Burrell, who is the chairperson of it and the principal of the secondary college, should be appreciated, encouraged and rewarded. I would also like to add that the Connections Program at the Monterey Secondary College seeks to achieve the same objectives, and I would be delighted to inform the House of those at a later point in time. Tourism

Speaker: Mr MARTIN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Cunningham) (5.55 p.m.}-I will be brief tonight in my comments about some tourism issues. I cannot believe that my tongue-in-cheek comments, as reported in the Illawarra Mercury, could get so many people in the government so excited. When I was talking about the opportunity to rev up Illawarra tourism in the adjournment debate earlier this week, the member for Macquarie (Mr Bartlett) and the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) scurried in here and proceeded to attack me. The simple fact of the matter is that anyone who knows anything about tourism could not be other than impressed by the fact that the Blue Mountains and the Hunter Valley do things extremely well. I have been to both locations in recent times. As a matter of fact, I was up in the Hunter Valley a week or so ago. Since I have been the shadow minister for tourism, that was probably the third or fourth time. I have been there. I was in the Port Stephens area, I was at Maitland, I was at Nelson Bay, and I met with people from the tourism industry there and talked about the great product that each of them has to sell. I was impressed by the way in which the Hunter Regional Tourism Organisation has gone about its particular way of doing things. The point that I was making, and which I am afraid was missed by those on the other side with less than a thorough understanding of tourism, was that in the Illawarra we have to do it better. My comments have received instant recognition. I am delighted to be able to tell the House that, in the year 2000, the ACTU congress is going to be held in W ollongong in the new sports entertainment centre, a centre that is being constructed at the present minute courtesy of a $17 million grant from the state government, for which we will be eternally grateful to Bob Carr. This follows hard on the heels of the news that 3,000 delegates will be coming for an International Lion's Club conference in Wollongong in the year 2001. It would seem that at long last people in Wollongong are getting their act together when it comes to tourism. We have so many attractions, both natural and man made. The point again that I would make-and I hope it is repeated in the Blue Mountains and in the Hunter Valley-is that we are going to compete against you. We are going to compete against you for those tourists who go for the beauty of the Blue Mountains and for the wine industry in the Hunter Valley, and I make no apology for that at all. We have the Illawarra, with Australia's industry world, with its hotels, with its beaches, with the indoor sports entertainment centre and with its great rugby league team. All of those are attractions which we will be promoting. I say to the rest of Australia that Wollongong and the Illawarra are coming after you in the tourism market. We recognise the value of tourism to Australia's economy. We also recognise the damage the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) and her One Nation Party are causing the tourism industry in broader Australia and we are not going to put up with it. Despite her best endeavours, we will be attempting to attract not only domestic but international tourists to the Illawarra. The Blue Mountains, in the federal seat of Macquarie, and the Hunter Valley, in the electorate of Paterson, should certainly be warned. In any case, I will conclude on this point. Bob Home is going to be here. He knows the true value of tourism-he showed me around the other day-as do the people in the Hunter Valley. He will be here more properly representing them after the next election. Fraser, Mrs u.: Death

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I thank the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) for allowing me to say a couple of words before the House adjourns. It has just come to my notice that on Saturday, 16 May, a very distinguished Australian, the mother of former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser, died. Mrs Una Fraser was the mother of Laurie and Malcolm. She was an extraordinarily cultured, delightful and traditional lady who made, in her own right, a very significant contribution in a range of intellectual pursuits. As one who worked with Malcolm and knew Mrs Una Fraser best during those days when he was Prime Minister, I can assure all Australians that she had a remarkable impact not only on Malcolm but on us all. She was very much a lady of her generation. She was truly a wonderful reflection of the best of the 20th century. On behalf of all members of this parliament, I would like to extend our deepest sympathy to Malcolm, Tammy and their family and to Laurie, and to say how proud they must be to have had such a wonderful person as their mother and friend. Fraser, Mrs U.: Death

Rather, it will come about to differentiate one person from another you need Main Committee adjourned at 1.30 p.m. NA The following answers to questions were circulated: Terminal Access: Petroleum Companies (Question No. 2189) Mr Latham asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 September 1997: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 1305 (Hansard, 27 August 1997, page 7042), what information and commitments have each of the major oil companies conveyed to him in response to his correspondence of 23 December 1996. (2) When does he expect each of the major oil companies to open their terminals for competitive access. Mr Costello-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) I do not disclose the contents of correspondinvited ence. However, Caltex Australia Ltd (trading as both Caltex and Ampol) is publicly committed to open access of their seaboard terminals as soon as price deregulation is implemented. (2) BP Australia Limited have already publicly established an open access regime through its terminal gate pricing system. I cannot speak on behalf of the other oil majors although I note that all are committed to introduce a system of open access in the event of full deregulation of the industry. Government Purchasing (Question No. 2268) Mrs West asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 24 September 1997: Further to my question without notice (Hansard, 17 June 1997, page 5362) concerning Government purchasing, has the Government introduced initiatives to maintain and increase the policy of 10% of Commonwealth purchases being made from small business; if so, what. Mr Fahey-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: On 8 August 1997 Commonwealth, State and Territory Procurement and Construction Ministers agreed to endorse the adoption of the 'National Action on Small to Medium Enterprises in Government Procurement' as an agreed strategy to imNA prove the access of SMEs to Government procurement opportunities, especially in regional Australia. The agreed national actions include measures that: reduce the cost of doing business for SMEs and for government; encourage greater participation by SMEs in the contract chain; promote the benefits to SMEs of the use of electronic commerce; and give greater consideration to the regional impact of government procurement decision making. The Department of Finance and Administration is progressing initiatives to advance the national actions. The former National Procurement Board also conducted seminars around Australia and SMEs to comment on aspects of Government procurement. The Government announced new streamlined and simplified Commonwealth purchasing arrangements in December 1997 to cut the cost of doing business with Federal Government departments and to provide greater opportunities for small business to participate in Government markets. The key initiatives included: maintenance of the Government's election commitment that Commonwealth departments and agencies source at least 10% of their purchases from small and medium enterprises (SMEs); inclusion of industry development requirements and opportunities for SMEs in tender documents for major projects valued at over $10 million; abolition of the commission imposed on businesses supplying to government under Common Use Arrangements with effect from December 1997; establishment of a pre-qualification scheme for businesses supplying in specific markets where the government is a major purchaser. The primary aim of the scheme is to reduce the cost for suppliers and buyers in doing business; establishment in March 1998 of a Purchasing Advisory and Complaints Service within the Department of Finance and Administration to assist suppliers (particularly SMEs) with problems they may experience with departmental purchasing processes. Long Term Operating Plan: Winds (Questiou No. 2615) Mr MCClelland asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: How many pilots have been directed to use long term operating landing patterns in cross winds over 15 knots since the (a) first and (b) second stages of implementation of the Long Term Operating Plan. Mr Vaile-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Airservices Australia advises that pilots are not directed to use particular runways. Airservices Australia nominates runways based on a number of criteria relating to wind/weather, airport efficiency and Government noise sharing objectives. Under these criteria runways are nominated with up to 25 knots of cross winds. It is the sole responsibility of the pilot to ensure that the runway nominated is suitable for the operation of the aircraft in the prevailing conditions. Long Term Operating Plan: Landing (Question No. 2616) Mr MCClelland asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: How many aircraft have been directed to use Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) landing patterns in conditions oflow cloud since the (a) first and (b) second stages of implementation of the LTOP. Mr Vaile-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Airservices Australia advises that pilots are not directed to use particular runways. Airservices Australia nominates runways based on a number of criteria relating to wind/weather, airport efficiency and Government noise sharing objectives. It is the sole responsibility of the pilot to ensure that the runway nominated is suitable for the operation of the aircraft in the prevailing conditions. Consolidated records of cloud conditions during the nomination of a particular runway are not readily available. Long Term Operating Plan: Pilots (Question No. 2617) Mr MCClelland asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: (1) How many times have pilots refused Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) based landing directions since the (a) first and (b) second stages of implementation of the LTOP. (2) What are the details of the circumstances in which the directions were refused. (3) What reasons were provided by pilots for using a non-LTOP landing pattern. Mr Vaile-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) and (2) Airservices Australia advises that details are not readily available of the number of times and the circumstances in which pilots have indicated that they have an operational requirement for other than the nominated arrival runway. (3) Airservices Australia advises that it does not ask pilots the reasons why they require other than the nominated runway. Standard Terminal Arrivals (Question No. 2618) Mr MCClelland asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: Pattern Has the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) identified standard terminal arrivals route related procedures which do not follow accepted world best practice: if so, (a) which procedures, (b) in what way do they fail to comply with world best practice and (c) what reasons has BASI discovered for world best practice not being achieved. Mr Vaile-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (a) The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) published a report in January 1997 entitled An Analysis of Incidents Involving Aircrew Failing to Comply with Air Traffic Clearances June to August 1996. The analysis included a review of the development and design of standard arrival routes (STARs) in Australia and also identified a number of then current air traffic control (ATC) procedures relating to STARs which did not follow accepted worldwide practice. (b)and (c) BASI's analysis found that generally, worldwide practice is for ATC to issue a STAR that leads an aircraft to a position from which an instrument approach can be made. However, on the basis of STARs procedures in place during the survey period June to August 1996, this practice was not always the case in Australia. For example, STARs then currently in place at Melbourne generally positioned the aircraft to join an instrument approach, whereas at Sydney, Brisbane and Perth, STARs culminated with an expectation that the aircraft would be vectored by radar to join the final approach course. Furthermore, ATC could instruct aircraft to cancel and subsequently resume flying a STAR, a procedure which is not in accordance with accepted international practice. BASI's analysis also found that compared with accepted worldwide practice, many Australian STARs included lengthy transition legs which aircraft were required to fly from an airways route to join the STAR. mits report, BASI made a number of recommendations to Airservices Australia which addressed issues associated with aligning STARs procedures to accepted worldwide practice including the need to: minimise vectoring aircraft within the STAR environment minimise the practice of instructing resume a STAR after having been vectored off a STAR ensure that STARs at all locations are designed with consistent design principles ensure STAR designs are compatible with aircraft flight management systems (FMS) especially where STARs are not runway specific. Proposed Second Sydney Airport: Rail (Question No. 2630) Mr Latham asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: (1) Has his Department entered negotiations with the NSW Government to site a rail link between Glenfield and the proposed second Sydney Airport at Badgerys Creek; if so, at what stage are the negotiations. (2) Has it been proposed to acquire land owned by Hurlstone Agricultural High School in Glenfield to facilitate the process. Mr Vaile-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) and (2) The suitability of the Badgerys Creek site for the development of a major airport is presently the subject of an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) process. The Draft EIS discusses two alternative route options for providing rail access between Glenfield and Badgerys Creek. Investigations undertaken by the Commonwealth and the NSW Government some years ago have been taken into account in developing the rail route options. Responsibility for acquisition of land for the expansion of Sydney's metropolitan rail network rests with the NSW Government. There is no current action by the Commonwealth to fund the acquisition of any land for a possible rail corridor between Glenfield and the Badgerys Creek airport site. Any Commonwealth involvement in the provision of rail access to Badgerys Creek will be dependent on the outcome of the second Sydney airport EIS process. Judicial Committee of the Privy Council (Question No. 2700) Mr Melham asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 March 1998. Is he able to say which countries have (a) allowed appeals or (b) ceased to allow appeals to the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council since the answer to question No. 1927 (Hansard, 30 aircraft to March 1995, page 2679). Mr Williams-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The source of the following information is Whitaker's Almanac 1998. (a) The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council is primarily the final court of appeal for the United Kingdom dependent territories and those independent Commonwealth countries which have retained the avenue of appeal upon achieving independence as follows-Antigua and Barbuda, Link The Bahamas Barbados, Belize, Brunei, Dominica, The Gambia, Jamaica, Kiribati, Mauritius, New Zealand, St Christopher and Nevis, St Lucia, St Vincent and the Grenadines, Trinidad and Tobago, and Tuvalu. The Committee also hears appeals from the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man. (b) Since the answer to the House of Representatives Question No. 1927, appeals to the Privy Council are no longer allowed from the following countries and territories Akrotiri, Bermuda, British Antarctica Territory, British Indian Ocean Territory, Cayman Islands, Dhekelia, Falkland Islands, Gibraltar, Guernsey, Hong Kong, Jersey, Monserrat, Pitcairn, St Helena, Turks and Caicos Islands and Virgin Islands. Jandakot Airport: Noise Study (Question No. 2703) Dr Lawrence asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 953 (Hansard, 15 May 1997, page 3720), did the Federal Airports Corporation refer the report of the J andakot Airport noise study to his Department in early April 1997. (2) Have the findings of the report been released for public comment; if not, why not. (3) When will the final report be released. Mr Vaile-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes. (2) and (3) The final report of the Jandakot Airport Noise Study was released by the Federal Airports Corporation in January 1998. Essendon Airport: Touch and Go (Question No. 2730) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 10 March 1998: (1) Is it a fact that on 24 January 1998 between 6 p.m. and 6.10 p.m. an aircraft with call sign Oscar Victor Oscar Harvard made four touch and go circuits at Essendon Airport involving ten movements including the proper take-of and landing. (2) Is it also a fact that the pilot, in asking for clearance for landing at Point Cook, observed that he would upset the neighbours if he did more touch and goes at Essendon Airport. (3) Are the operations described on part (1) inappropriate for Essendon Airport; if so what action will he take to ensure that they are undertaken at Point Cook rather than Essendon. Mr Vaile-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (l) Airservices Australia advise that the aircraft in question operated as described except that the tenth movement was about one hour latcr when the aircraft returned from Point Cook. (2) Airservices Australia advises that it has no reports on this matter. (3) Circuits by single-engined aircraft are permitted at Essendon for the purpose of test flights and pilot endorsements. Airservices Australia advises that it's operational procedures do not give Air Traffic Controllers the authority to question the purpose of particular flights. (2) Has his attention been drawn to a press release entitled "Joe Hockey and Mode 6A" issued by the Member for Wentworth on 3 March 1998; if so, are statements relating to the matter referred to in part (1) which are contained in the press release accurate. Mr Vaile-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Neither I nor my office have been involved in discussions on the fanning out of flight paths over the eastern suburbs. The possibility of fanning out of flight paths over the eastern suburbs was raised briefly, but not taken up, at the meeting of the Implementation and Monitoring Committee held on 20 January 1998. The introduction of mode 6A was discussed at the meetings of the Implementation and Monitoring Committee held on 20 January 1998, 17 February 1998 and 10 March 1998. A representative of the Department was present at these meetings. (2) I and Members of the Implementation and Monitoring Committee were aware of the proposed mode 6A on the date of the media release. M5Freeway (Question No. 2809) Mr Latham asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 26 March 1998: Further to the answer to question No.37 (Hansard, 20 August 1996, page 3286) what is the (a) priority status of the proposed construction of on and off ramps south of Brooks Road on the M5 freeway at Ingleburn, NSW ; (b) progress of discussions between his Department and the NSW Roads and Traffic Authority regarding this matter and (c) expected commencement date for the project. phase is given a defined meaning, any other part of speech or other grammatical form in respect of that word or phrase has a corresponding meaning. Mr Vaile-The answer to the honourahle Paths member's question is as follows: (a) No decision has yet been made on the priority status of funding for construction of the F5 ramps. The Government is funding a $100,000 traffic study in 1997/98 to investigate the need for additional entry and exit ramps along the F5. The study, to be completed by mid-1998, is examining the need for ramps at the intersections of Raby Road, St Andrews Road, Campbelltown Road and Brooks Road in the Ingleburn and Minto area. (b) The Department of Transport and Regional Development has discussed the ,possible need for additional ramps with the NSW Roads and Traffic Authority (RTA) in the context of the National Highway forward program in NSW. These discussions have also raised the possible need to develop joint funding arrangements with NSW, relevant councils and private sector developers. (c) A commencement date and funding arrangements will be determined when the results of the current study are available. Mr MCLachlan-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The information required is available in various Defence Department databases but presenting the information requested by the honourable member poses the following problems: (a) the raw database printout of the exercises, without the costing information, is over 160 pages and it would take considerable time and effort to extract the information sought; (b) some of the information on exercises is classified; and (c) some of the costing information is not readily available. Aboriginal Organisations: Supply of Motor Vehicles (Question No. 2871) Mr Hicks asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 7 April 1998: What sum has been spent with each vehicle manufacturer in supplying vehicles to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and other Commonwealth funded Aboriginal organisations in each year since 1993.

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: TION
text: The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) Nil. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission does not deal with vehicle manufacturers, however it sources its vehicles through DASFLEET. Aboriginal organisations can be funded for the purchase of motor vehicles to assist in the completion of their funded activities. Where motor vehicles are purchased it is the client who decides what type of vehicle most addresses their need. It is not feasible to compile a definitive response, even to the extent that it would be possible, due to the level of resources it would require. NA Aboriginal Hostels Limited The Aboriginal Hostels Limited has not directly paid a sum of money to any vehicle manufacturer for the supply of vehicles, in each year since 1993. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation does not purchase vehicles. The small number of vehicles utilised by the ATSICDC is obtained through DASFLEET and ownership of the vehicles rests with that organisation. Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders Studies AIATSIS has a policy of owning rather than leasing vehicles. The following prices are the amount spent (as asked for) ie purchase price after trade-in. 1993 Mitsubishi $12,464; 1994 ditto $7447; 1995 ditto nil Ford $11,189; 1996 ditto $10,999; 1997 ditto nil Ford $9,255. Torres Strait Regional Authority The Torres Strait Regional Authority was created on July 1 1994. All TSRA administration vehicles are leased through DASFLEET. Our record system does not allow us to identify individual lease payments only a combined monthly lease payment is made for all cars. Combined lease payments for administration vehicles are as follows: 1994/95$13,886; 1995/96-$22,482; 1996/97-$20,292; 1997/98-$23,858 (July to April). The following make of vehicles are currently leased from DASFLEET: Toyota Camry, Nissan Navara, Toyota Spacia, Ford Futura. The following are vehicles that have been previously leased from DASFLEET: Toyota Tarago, Toyota Camry, Toyota Ute, Toyota Tarago. Organisations and Councils funded through TSRA programs may purchase vehicles if they are required for the effective running of that organisation. Each Council/Organisation decides which vehicle most suits the need of their organisation. More generally, the ILC has purchased a number of pastoral properties on a "walk-in, walk-out" basis. The majority of vehicles purchased by island councils from Commonwealth funds are in order to operate the Community Development Employment Programs. Indigenous Land Corporation The Indigenous Land Corporation (ILC) has not purchased any motor vehicles for use by ILC staff since its establishment on 1 June 1995. The ILC's current in-house motor vehicle requirements are met through the term leasing of four (4) Holden and two (2) Mitsubishi motor cars from DASFLEET in Adelaide, Perth and Brisbane and one (I) Holden motor car from City Holden in Adelaide. Mogila Merino Stud Pty Ltd (ACN 078 466 761), a wholly owned subsidiary of the ILC, purchased several new and second hand motor vehicles for on-farm use at Mogila Station, NSW. Brisbane Airport: Proposed Flight Paths (Question No. 2890) Mr Bevis asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 8 April 1998: (1) Do proposed flight paths exist in conjunction with the draft Brisbane Airport master plan released in March 1998: if so, (a) why were they not released with the draft master plan and (b) will he ensure they are released immediately. (2) What action will be taken to ensure that the effects of noise generated by increased air traffic over Brisbane and the number of residents affected are minimised. Mr Vaile-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The master plan process exposes the community to the airport owner's vision for the possible future development of the airport. It does provide approval, or imply that approval will be given, for any major projects such as new runways. Master plans have previously been released for Brisbane Airport in 1983, 1991 and 1995. None of these previous master plans have included flight paths for the proposed parallel runway. (a) The timing of the release of flight paths is primarily a matter for the airport owner. (b) Flight paths will be an important part of the environmental impact statement that will be required as part of any Major Development Plan such as a new runway, if that development were to be proposed in several years time. The Airports Act process does not allow a runway to be constructed until flight paths and all other environmental impacts are fully known to the community through an environmental impact statement process. (2) Brisbane Airport Corporation Limited (BACL) has provided information to the community which gives its commitment to minimising noise impacts on the community wherever and whenever practicable, in consultation with other stakeholders. The Corporation indicates that managing aircraft impacts to acceptable levels is a matter for the airlines, Airservices Australia, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, the Corporation itself, and land use planning authorities such as Brisbane City Council and State government agencies. Importantnot ly, under the Airports Act 1996, any Major Development Plan for constructing a new runway or extending the length of a runway is required to set out the airport owner's plans for managing aircraft noise intrusion, developed in consultations with the airlines, local government bodies in the vicinity of the airport, and the local community.
